This course aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the role that nanotechnology will play in the diagnosis and treatment of medical conditions in the future. This short course will look at how this rapidly developing field will impact human health and the challenges involved.  It will start by introducing the concept of nanotechnology, the fundamental physics, chemistry and biology underpinning the modern nanobiotechnology.  Special emphasis will be given equip the students with the knowledge of nano-bio interface (how nanomaterials interact with human blood, cells and tissues).  After the discussion of modern technology platforms that are used to characterize nanoparticles, the current application of nanotechnology in medicine will be explored.  All examples of the application of medical nanobiotechnology will be taken from current SCI publications. Latest development in the application of nanobiotechnology to medicine will be  introduced via examples in nano carrier-based drug delivery, cancer nanomedicine, diagnostic imaging, and nenoregenerative medicine.  Finally, the potential risks of nanotechnology and how to manage them (nanotoxicology) will be discussed.

生命分析化学是一门新的交叉学科，它以生命物质为对象，综合运用高效、快速、简便、准确的分析手段，来解决生命科学中定性、定量的重大问题。故要求与分析化学、生物学和仪器科学与技术等相关学科更加紧密地结合。生命体系自身的各种复杂过程迫切需要超高灵敏度、选择性、活体、原位、实时和在线等新型分析方法、技术和仪器，了解生命特征离不开科学分析技术手段，生命科学的快速发展也为分析化学的创新提出了更高要求。生命分析化学的发展不仅促进生命科学的进步，而且会推进与之相关的临床医学、化学科学、环境科学等研究领域的发展，甚至对国家安全建设、国民经济发展、国民生活提升都有重大战略意义和现实意义。目前，虽然教育部目前还没有制定生命分析化学本科专业培养方案的规范化意见，但国内已经有部分高校依据自己的实际情况制定了该课程的教学方案，而我院尚未正式开设该门课程。
1.生命分析化学基本的原理和测定方法。2.生命分析仪器的原理及其应用实例，了解与这些主要分析方法有关的数据采集和处理办法。3.生命分析化学领域的前沿研究和突破性领域。

This course presents that variation of meat quality exist because the quality traits are affected by various intrinsic and extrinsic factors. Because the meat quality is basically dependent on muscle fiber characteristics, the relationship between quality traits and fiber characteristics will be explained. Also, this course suggests several potential ways to manipulate muscle fiber characteristics to improve meat quality. Cloning and Stem Cells: Business Opportunities
Cloning and Stem Cells: Business Opportunities

This course will focus on genetic reprogramming of cells to generate animals and cellular systems for agricultural and medical applications. The last decade brought a great progress in discoveries of (epi)genetic reprogramming of cells in order to generate animals (somatic cell nuclear transfer, “cloning” technology) or immortal cell lines for biomedical applications (induced pluripotent stem cell technology). The outstanding importance of the field has been recognized by a Noble Prize in Medicine in 2012 for Sir John Gurdon and Prof Shinya Yamanaka. Currently the first medical and commercial applications are arising. The course will provide theoretical and technical details in the genetic reprogramming field, with numerous practical examples of potential commercial use of the methods in animal breeding, drug  development, regenerative medicine and “in vitro” toxicology. Special emphasis will be given to human cellular models and possible treatments of central nervous system diseases, where the first clinical trials are starting. Furthermore, animal welfare, ethical considerations and legal regulations of micro-manipulation and genetic reprogramming methods will be discussed, as major factors affecting the commercial viability. Finally, intellectual property issues of biotechnological innovations as highly relevant for the future of industrialization of the technology will be presented.

植物分类学实验是紧密结合《植物系统分类学》理论课程而开设的实验课。本课程2学分，48学时，包括13个实验。通过这些实验操作，使学生了解和掌握植物分类学的基本知识和基本实验技能。内容包括孢子植物类群的藻类、苔藓、蕨类等，种子植物包括裸子植物常见科：苏铁科、银杏科、松科、杉科、柏科、罗汉松科等6个科，被子植物包括木兰科、毛茛科至兰科共34个科，共计掌握种子植物这40个常见科的科鉴定特征、及其常见属的属鉴定特征，以及具有经济价值的常见种的识别等。实验注重利用活体实验材料和腊叶标本材料，突出培养学生自主鉴定和使用植物科属种检索表的能力。同时通过校园植物综合考察，有助于学生将课堂知识与大自然结合起来，将微观与宏观，局部与整体结合起来，大大提高学生的学习兴趣。

This course will cover forefront statistical and bioinformatics analysis tools for analyzing biomedical data, particularly genomic data. Traditional analysis methods as well as modern machine-learning approaches, such as regularized regression, classification, regression trees, deep learning, will be covered. Programming language, such as R, will also be introduced for hands-on practice. Students will be prepared for handlingcommon analysis tasks in the data-science era.

A huge, diverse chemical arsenal of biologically active substances are produced as defensive, offensive or signaling agents in interactions between organisms, which need to establish and maintain their territorial positions. Deciphering the role of these biologically active substances will contribute to our understanding of the role of the microorganism that produce them in the functioning of marine ecosystems, particularly on the biology of host organisms such as sponges or corals. In addition such understanding may provide the raw material for drug discovery. The harvest of wild populations is unlikely to provide an ecologically sustainable source of bioactive compounds for development. In addition this method is unlikely to provide relevant amounts of these substances therefore the use of mariculture techniques and molecular biological approaches may be an alternative and provide enough material for chemical synthesis. The Marine Drug Discovery course deals with the marine natural products chemistry and biology. Topics include: Organism biology and ecology, bioassays, screening, and molecular aspects of biosynthetic pathways of secondary metabolites.
The World of Recombinant / Genetically Modified Organisms Around Us
The World of Recombinant / Genetically Modified Organisms Around Us

The course starts with the brief description on alterations in the genome of different organisms (both natural and manmade). The course is going to provide the first hand information on available methods of creating genetically modified organisms (both prokaryotic and eukaryotic). The available GMO with respect to their applications will be discussed from all possible sectors starting from household to industrial to health and wellbeing to agriculture and so on. An introduction to the available regulatory framework around the world on the use of GMO will be discussed. Various controversies with respect to the use of GMOs will be discussed as case studies. The course will end with the discussion on the ethical issues related to the generation and use of GMOs in various parts of the world.

More than half of all infections that people get are spread by animals. Diseases like rabies, Salmonella, and West Nile virus infections are examples of zoonotic diseases (or zoonoses)— diseases that can be shared between animals and people. 
Every year, tens of thousands of people will get sick from diseases spread between animals and people. Animals can sometimes serve as early warning signs of potential illness in people. For example, birds often die of West Nile virus before people get sick with West Nile virus fever. The health of people is connected to the health of animals and our shared environment. A One Health approach encourages collaborative efforts of many experts (like disease detectives, laboratorians, physicians, and veterinarians) working across human, animal, and environmental health to improve the health of people and animals. The present course will introduce the students in as well medical as policy aspects of the One health-One world approach by introducing the international frame and by giving specific zoonotic diseases examples.
The content of this course is consisted of the followings：The one world one health concept; International framework and regulation (Example OIE); emergency plans; laboratory network; biosecurity in laboratory practice; epidemiology and risk assessment.  Examples: classical swine fever; African swine fever; encephalomyocarditis virus; pathogens transmitted by food: introduction to microbiological food safety: food borne outbreaks: case studies.

The course will discuss issues involved in entrepreneurship in biotechnology as well as teach the student to write a pitch based on either a novel idea they will formulate or an idea provided to them.

The course teaches the students the various issues involved in spinning off a technology from a University setting into a start-up venture. The students will also learn how to make a slide deck pitch based on either on an idea of theirs or one given to them. The course will teach them how to make a pitch so they can go raise capital based on their idea. We start the technology readiness of the product or prototype. Of importance will be the marketing work where students learn that an idea is rarely good unless validated by interviews to beachhead end-users. Interview techniques are introduced and the sport of chasing interviews begins. Patents and their importance will be discussed. We discuss the importance in comparing the idea to competition and learning how to bring out the value proposition. We will articulate the technical specification for a minimally viable product. Then formulate a development roadmap with key milestones. Course is divided into modules. The business model derives from the aforementioned. Throughout the course the mentor will coach the students in their various projects. The course ends with them presenting their pitch and defending it.
